questions.text: Wildlife killing contests are organized events in which participants compete for cash or prizes for killing wild animals—most often coyotes, foxes, raccoons, or squirrels in Indiana—within a specified time period. These contests typically run 24 to 48 hours and end with organizers counting or weighing animals to award prizes for the most, largest, or smallest killed. In some contests, several hundred animals have been killed. Do you think it is acceptable or unacceptable to hold or participate in wildlife killing contests in Indiana? Acceptable Unacceptable

questions.text: Many state wildlife officials and hunters have expressed concern that wildlife killing contests may harm the reputation of sportsmen and sportswomen and public support for hunting. Public surveys show that Americans continue to support hunting overall but are less supportive of practices they view as inhumane or wasteful. In response, ten U.S. states have now prohibited wildlife killing contests. Do you support or oppose a ban on wildlife killing contests in Indiana? Support Oppose

questions.text: This fall, Indiana will allow its first bobcat trapping season since bobcats were protected in the 1960s. The Natural Resources Commission approved a quota – that is, the number of bobcats allowed to be killed – of 250 bobcats. The Department of Natural Resources did not provide data to demonstrate any need to kill 250 bobcats. The trapping season will allow recreational trappers to kill bobcats and sell their fur to overseas markets. Do you support or oppose the bobcat trapping season? Support Oppose
questions.full_text:
This fall, Indiana will allow its first bobcat trapping season since bobcats were protected in the 1960s. The Natural Resources Commission approved a quota – that is, the number of bobcats allowed to be killed – of 250 bobcats. The Department of Natural Resources did not provide data to demonstrate any need to kill 250 bobcats. The trapping season will allow recreational trappers to kill bobcats and sell their fur to overseas markets. Do you support or oppose the bobcat trapping season?

Support

questions.text: The majority of the public comments received during the public comment period opposed the bobcat trapping season proposal, and many supported a bobcat trapping quota of zero, meaning no bobcats would be killed. Do you believe that the Natural Resources Commission should have given more serious consideration to the majority of public comments?

questions.text: In Indiana, it is currently legal to trap coyotes, red foxes, gray foxes, and raccoons, remove them from the wild, and keep them in captivity—confined to a cage—for several months without a permit. This may be done to collect urine from the animal to make or sell trapping lure for recreational trappers. Do you believe taking animals from the wild and keeping them in captivity in this manner should be allowed in Indiana? Yes, it should be allowed No, it should not be allowed

Following an incident in Sturgeon, MO in 2023, where a small blind and deaf family dog named Teddy was fatally shot by a police officer, the Legislature is considering a bill aimed at preventing future shootings. The bill, known as “Teddy’s Law,” would require all law enforcement officers to complete training on how to safely handle encounters with dogs using proven, non-lethal de-escalation methods. Would you support or oppose this legislation?

Support
Oppose
